options.A: young female patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and a symptomatic posterior communicating artery (PComm) aneurysm presents for management. What is the next step in her treatment?

question_text: An elderly patient with confusion, seizure, and weakness was brought to the emergency department. MRI of the brain showed multiple cortical microhemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?

options.A: Amyloid-beta related angiitis

75-year-old female with diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with right-sided weakness for one week. MRI shows a left internal capsule lacunar infarction, and vascular workup reveals right ICA 55% stenosis and left ICA 65% stenosis. What should be done for her regarding stroke prevention?

question_text: In the context of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), which statement is correct?

options.A: The ICH score is for mortality, including age, GCS, IVH volume, and coagulopathy as risk factors.
options.B: The spot sign is not beneficial for reverse anticoagulation.
options.C: Early surgical evacuation is recommended for all small deep hemorrhages.
options.D: Blood pressure lowering has no impact on hematoma expansion in ICH.

question_text: What is the diagnosis for a 40-year-old female, medically free, with a previous history of two miscarriages, presenting with left side weakness, normal CBC, normal INR, normal chemistry, elevated ESR, and positive ANA?

options.A: Cerebral vasculitis

50-year-old male presents with progressive lower limb weakness and a sensory level up to T10. There is no upper limb involvement. MRI of the spine shows thoracic and conus hyperintensity surrounded by a hypointense rim. The neurological examination reveals upgoing plantar responses and absent reflexes in the lower limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
patient with SLE and antiphospholipid syndrome presented with a stroke for 2 days. What will you give?

question_text: In a patient with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and normal CTA and attached CT, what is the recommended management?

options.A: Evacuation
young female with a history of stroke and recurrent abortions is evaluated. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

30-year-old female presents with an 18-month history of back pain, weakness, numbness, and sphincter issues. On examination, there is a sensory level up to T10, with upgoing plantar responses and absent ankle reflexes. MRI of the thoracic spine shows high signal T2 with a hypointense center. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: MRI (DWI) shows multiple infarctions on one side. What is the next step in management?

options.A: CTA
girl with a history of migraine headaches, stroke, and dementia, along with a family history of similar issues in her father presents for evaluation. What is your diagnosis?
patient with SLE and antiphospholipid syndrome presented with a stroke for 2 days. What should be administered?

question_text: Which cranial nerve is primarily responsible for the sense of smell?

options.A: Optic nerve (CN II)

question_text: The risk of stroke increases with which of the following conditions?

options.A: Tension-type headache

question_text: Based on the following brain MRI, what is the most likely mechanism of injury?

options.A: ICA stenosis

45-year-old patient with a history of migraine 15 years ago developed a TIA. His father has a history of stroke. MRI involving the anterior temporal lobe was performed. What is the next best step in management?
patient presents with a skin rash (Angiokeratomas) and a family history of stroke. What is the gene associated with this condition?
case scenario of a patient with CADASIL presents with stroke, dementia, and migraine. What is the best way to diagnose this condition?
male patient with renal impairment, stroke, and angiokeratoma is being evaluated for enzyme supplementation. Which enzyme is likely deficient?

patient with recurrent epistaxis and telangiectasia over the skin, mucous membranes, retina, and gastrointestinal tract is suspected to have hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. What is the next best step in management?

question_text: What was the aggregate risk reduction of stroke at 10 years for patients with 70% to 99% ICA stenosis undergoing carotid endarterectomy (CEA) according to the ACST trial?

options.A: From 17.9% in best medical treatment to 13.4% in CEA

20-year-old male with a history of learning difficulty presented to the clinic with his father due to repeated history of stroke-like symptoms, dysarthria, and hearing loss. MRI of the brain was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: What is a new recommendation for adults with acute ischemic stroke who have known sickle cell disease?

options.A: IV alteplase may be beneficial

question_text: In a case of malignant MCA infarction presented after 24 hours with midline shift, what is the most important intervention?

options.A: Decompressive craniectomy
